'''Epidemiology'''

- HHV6 virus (Herpesviridae family, beta-herpesvirinae subfamily, roseolovirus genus)

- human-to-human transmission via the respiratory route (saliva, droplets)

- primary infection in early childhood, then lifelong latency, with potentially severe reactivation in immunocompromised patients (Herpes virus)


Clinical characteristics (primary infection)

'''-'''' incubation 5 to 15 days

often asymptomatic

- symptomatic form (roseola): 2 phases

           - pre-eruptive (invasion): high fever with general signs lasting 1 to 6 days (average 3 days)

           - eruptive: ''maculopapular exanthema'', pink ''pale'', face and trunk, ''fleeting'', 24 hours. Fever disappears with the rash (diagnostic argument).


Treatment is symptomatic

Complications are rare (neurological)

question.title: What is the typical presentation of primary infection in children with HHV6 virus?

option_a.title: A high fever with general signs lasting 1 to 6 days, followed by a maculopapular exanthema

option_b.title: A sudden onset of a severe rash, accompanied by high fever and general signs

option_c.title: A lifelong latency period, with potentially severe reactivation in immunocompromised patients

option_d.title: A primary infection in early childhood, followed by lifelong latency, with potentially severe reactivation in immunocompromised patients

correct_option.title: D
correct_option.description: This consists only a letter of the correct option
